I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  a  country  program  reconfirmation  mission  following  the  election  of  the  new 
Government in Papua New Guinea (PNG), the Government reconfirmed the request that the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide technical assistance (TA) to comprehensively review 
agricultural  and  natural  resource  policies  and  strategies  and  prepare  a  project  for  ADB 
financing.1 At the Government’s request, a two-phase process will be followed: (i) phase 1—
review  and  participatory  strategy  development,  and  (ii)  phase  2—project  preparation.  The 
Government has agreed with the TA goals, purpose, scope and implementation arrangements, 
cost and financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Nonmining rural industries offer direct employment and food security for about 87% of 
the  population,  and  about  30%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  comes  from  agriculture, 
forestry, and fishing. Key agricultural industries (apart from oil palm) have generally performed 
poorly in the past two decades, leading to declining export earnings in dollar terms; rural 
employment has not expanded since 1980.2 Over 90% of the poor live in rural areas. The 
Government recently stated that a major cornerstone of its economic strategy will be reviving 
the  export  sector  and  supporting  rural  development.  However,  despite  improving 
competitiveness  of  exports  (and  of  domestically  produced  food)  following  the  significant 
depreciation of the kina (the national currency), the institutions and policies are not in place to 
get agriculture moving.3 The institutional fabric is highly fragmented, with many overlapping 
responsibilities and underresourced agencies at the national, provincial, industry, and sector 
levels. A coherent framework of policies and institutional arrangements is urgently required as 
part of a strategy for sustainable agriculture and natural resource development.  
 
3.  PNG has extremely diverse farming systems matched by diverse cultural traditions. A 
mixture of semisubsistence, exchange, and market-oriented production at the household level 
results  from  the  rugged  topography,  a  wide  range  of  agroecological  conditions,  significant 
linguistic and ethnic diversity, widely differing value systems and beliefs on many aspects of life, 
and different levels of social and economic development. The level of biodiversity is very high in 
the country. Of the total arable land area of about 12.5 million hectares (ha), only about 3% 
(400,000 ha) have high agricultural potential, and these areas are widely distributed and often a 
considerable distance from markets. Village-based agriculture is dominant, typically featuring a 
combination of food gardens, small stands of export crops, and livestock. Cash crop productivity 
levels for village agriculture are low compared to larger-scale operations on plantations or 
agribusiness operations. Most people live on land they own under customary arrangements, 
and about 97% of land is held under customary arrangements where formal title does not exist. 
Due to the rugged topography, infrastructure and maintenance costs are high. The extensive 
infrastructure system, constructed from the 1950s to the 1970s, which connected extensive rural 
areas to markets, has severely deteriorated due to neglect, transforming the outlook for the rural 
economy and severely constraining its options. 
 
4.  Services  to  support  these  diverse  farming  systems  have  not  been  adequately 
developed. Even in the early years following independence, when the rural economy was

relatively vibrant and export prices were high, the range of rural services was very basic. 
Effective rural financial services were generally not available for small farmers, but competitive 
marketing  services  were  to  most  producers;  and  roads  were  maintained  and  basic  social 
services operated effectively, albeit with limited access by many households. The quality and 
effectiveness of services have seriously declined in recent years, and the gradual decline of 
road, shipping, and airline coverage has reduced the possibility of delivering effective rural 
services.  Increasing  lawlessness  and  lack  of  employment,  combined  with  constrained  and 
ineffectively used government budgets, have had highly adverse consequences for rural life.  
 
5.  The Department of Agriculture and Livestock (DAL) is the central agency for agricultural 
policy, planning, and monitoring market trends, but has very limited capacity or resources to 
undertake its core functions and to effectively develop policies or advocate strategic directions. 
The provincial departments of primary industry (PDPIs), which are responsible for extension 
services,  are  similarly  starved  of  funds,  poorly  coordinated,  and  cannot  provide  effective 
services. At the industry level, clear ideas and plans as to the main priorities exist, but adequate 
resources are not available. Industry priorities are also not necessarily shared by the central 
Government, which has the responsibility for providing most budget resources. The lack of clear 
policy and implementation capacity has also led to a decline in international assistance to the 
sector.  
 
6.  Not all agricultural services have declined in quality. The National Agricultural Research 
Institute (NARI) has developed a farming systems approach and has close relationships with a 
broad  client  group  for  delivering  improved  productivity  approaches,  but  is  inadequately 
resourced despite international assistance, notably from Australia. Ongoing church-based rural 
services  are  often  extensive  and  effective  and  offer  potential  for  broad  replication. 
Nongovernment organizations (NGO) services are significant, but are localized. Some of the 
various specialized institutions, largely commodity based, operate relatively effectively, due in 
part to market-oriented administration and greater responsiveness to clients. Private sector 
initiatives  and  innovations  supported  by  external  funding  agencies  in  extension  services, 
microfinance,  or  linkages  to  value-added  markets  have  been  introduced  (especially  in  the 
nucleus-focused  industries),  but  not  adequately  mainstreamed.  Partnerships  between 
government services and civil-society groups are few, but given the highly localized nature of 
PNG  society  and  the  tradition  of  a  wide  range  of  private  stakeholders  in  the  agricultural 
economy, scope is considerable to rapidly expand services in rural PNG, building on effective 
partnerships between government and nongovernment groups.4 
 
7.  Although a number of insightful external reviews have emerged in recent years and the 
state of the rural economy has been well analyzed, many recommendations in these reports 
have  not  been  adequately  debated  or  even  considered  in  Government,  although  valuable 
dialogue has occurred in the private sector. Despite these and other reviews, and excellent 
analytical  data  on  the  status  of  agricultural  systems  and  potential  at  the  provincial  level, 
inadequate use has been made of this work. The arguments in support of policy, institutional, or 
technical innovations in the agriculture sector have not been convincingly made at the central 
government level, and action to arrest sector decline has been inadequate. This is largely due to 
the lack of a consensus on reform within the Government and uncertainty about what needs to 
be  done.  Hence,  public  investment  has  inadequately  addressed  the  needs  of  the  sector, 
including for transport. The trend in recent years may have worsened as the economy has 
contracted and expenditures have been constrained.

8.  As PNG’s fiscal situation has declined significantly in recent years and the medium-term 
outlook is bleak, successful implementation of a viable strategy will also require streamlining of 
institutions to align with budget reality and focus more attention on the rural economy.5 The 
tightening of the fiscal situation is due to a secular decline in mineral revenues, exacerbated in 
2002 by overexpenditure during the first half of the year. Although the Government that came to 
power in August 2002 is taking drastic action to restrain expenditure, the stringency will need to 
be  sustained  over  the  medium  term,  which  requires  careful  streamlining  of  public  service 
programs and close attention to effectiveness, particularly to mitigate the poverty impacts.  
 
9.  The following are urgently needed: (i) a coherent strategy for the future, (ii) the main 
priority reforms and an appropriate sequence for improving the productivity of village agriculture 
and natural resource management, (iii) how these changes will best be implemented, and (iv) 
how the most important changes could be financed at a time of national fiscal crisis.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The  overall  goal  is  to  help  the  Government  articulate  and  then  implement  a  clear 
national vision for agriculture and natural resource development. The specific purpose of the TA 
is to prepare and gain consensus on a coherent strategy for agricultural and natural resource 
development and to formulate a project that will enable the Government to implement key 
elements of the strategy. This will be achieved through a two-phase process, beginning with 
agreement on the following four main outputs: (i) a consistent policy and legal framework, (ii) 
sector priorities and strategies covering the main domestic and export industries, (iii) defined 
key stakeholder mandates and roles, and (iv) an effective monitoring and learning mechanism. 
This work will be undertaken in a participatory manner in phase 1 of the TA. Phase 2 will build 
on the outputs of phase 1 and, if deemed appropriate, design a project for loan financing to help 
implement priority reforms and complementary development activities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Phase  1  of  the  TA  will  provide  an  agreed-on  and  fully  owned  sector  review  and 
participatory  strategy  development  as  a  basis  for  specific  project  design  in  phase  2.  An 
analytical review will be undertaken of the agriculture and natural resource sector and its recent 
performance and medium-term outlook. Recent studies, reviews, socioeconomic projections, 
and lessons learned from past projects will be fully considered. Key constraints to developing a 
coherent  strategy  for  agricultural  and  natural  resource  development  will  be  identified.  A 
summary rural outlook for the next decade will be prepared to brief participants in various 
workshops.  
 
12.  The following work will be covered in phase 1:  
 
(i)  Legislative and institutional review. The legal and regulatory arrangements 
and institutional mandates will be reviewed, placing attention on the consistency 
of national, provincial, and local laws and regulations and the effectiveness of 
enforcement.  Impediments  to  improved  market  efficiency  and  service

development will be identified, especially with respect to overlapping jurisdictions 
and  roles,  resource  availability,  and  the  need  for  streamlining.  Institutions' 
delivery  modalities  will  be  examined  to  see  where  they  are  most  and  least 
effective in providing services, especially for smallholder farming systems, and 
the requirements for reforms and capacity development. Innovations in services 
or other areas of ongoing reform will be examined for replication in a wider 
context. 
 
(ii)  Policies and strategies. The existing policy and strategy framework will be 
reviewed, based on recent government  papers, DAL corporate plans and briefs, 
and relevant policies and plans of the key industries. The review will identify  
(a) whether  the  policy  regime  is adequate  and  deliverable  to support  PNG’s 
complex farming systems and sustainable rural livelihoods, (b) policy consistency 
and areas where perverse incentives are provided and conflict with market-based 
principles,  (c)  coherence  between  agencies  and  industries,  (d)  areas  for 
improved donor coordination, and (e) enforcement capacity.  
 
(iii)  Public expenditure review and budget projections. A consolidated financial 
statement of all relevant service agencies (government and nongovernment) will 
be  prepared,  including  those  involved  in  financial  and  marketing  services, 
showing  past  trends  and  projections  for  the  next  5–10  years.  International 
comparisons  with  selected  Pacific  and  Asian  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs) will also be prepared. The extent to which the Government and the 
sector can afford the existing structure under the constrained fiscal outlook will 
be examined, and alternatives will be proposed to inform sector stakeholders, 
workshop participants, and other interested parties.  
 
(iv)  Participatory  workshops.  Workshops  on  the  various  crops  and  subsector 
groups (one per industry for coffee, cocoa, oil palm, copra, tea, rubber, fisheries, 
livestock, minor export crops, and food crops) will be conducted for up to 3 days 
each as required.6 The workshops will (a) consider the enabling environment for 
investment and development; (b) discuss and agree on the key constraints to 
sustainable development; (c) examine existing industry policies, strategies, and 
plans, and how to implement and/or amend them as needed; (d) examine service 
delivery effectiveness, including financial services; and (e) recommend an action 
plan and the sequencing of necessary actions. Feedback will be obtained from 
major stakeholders, including senior government officials, government agencies, 
farmers and local communities, input and output marketing agents, traders and 
financiers, research bodies, external agencies, and NGOs. The main outputs will 
be consensus on and ownership of key strategy elements and implementation 
arrangements.  Results  of  each  workshop  will  be  compiled  in  a  set  of 
recommendations.  
 
13.  Phase 2 will build from the results of the phase 1 and design a project, if appropriate, 
suitable for loan financing. Careful assessment of potential viability will be required before 
proceeding to project design. It will include economic, social, and environmental analyses. The 
proposed project will enable Government to implement key elements of the agreed-on strategy. 
Phase 2 will include a national policy seminar at the beginning, and a national stakeholder 
workshop to review the draft project design.

C.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
14.  The cost of the project will be $1.25 million equivalent, comprising $610,000 in foreign 
currency costs and $640,000 in local currency costs. ADB will finance all foreign currency costs 
and $390,000 of local currency costs. Government and domestic private sector agencies will 
finance $250,000 equivalent, largely in kind. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government has been advised 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Department of National Planning and Rural Development will be the TA Executing 
Agency and will provide guidance and overall coordination of the domestic agencies involved, 
including  DAL,  NARI,  PDPIs,  and  the  representative  agencies  for  key  industries.  A  TA 
implementation unit will coordinate implementation.  
 
16.  The TA will go on for about 12 months, from about March 2003 to March 2004. Phase 1 
(6 months) will require 10 person-months of international consultants and 16 person-months of 
domestic consultants. After a 1-month break to consider the results of phase 1, phase 2 (5 
months)  will  focus  on  project  preparation,  requiring  14  person-months  of  international 
consultants and 20 person-months of domestic consultants. International expertise will cover  
(i) agricultural and natural resources policy, (ii) institutions and capacity development, (iii) legal 
and regulatory aspects, (iv) rural financial markets, (v) marketing, (vi) research and extension 
services, and (vii) economic and financial analysis. Domestic expertise will cover (i) public 
policy/planning,  (ii) finance  and  budgeting,  (iii)  extension,  (iv) community  development,  and 
(v) legal and regulatory aspects. A firm of consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants,  and  selected  by  using  the  simplified  technical 
proposal  procedure  and  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method.  Equipment  will  be 
procured by the consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. As detailed 
in the terms of reference (Appendix 4), the consultants will submit four reports (inception, 
phase 1, draft final, final).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Papua New Guinea for Preparing the Agriculture and Rural Development 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) has requested assistance to develop a 
clear  national  vision  for  agricultural  and  natural  resource  development.  Nonmining  rural 
industries offer direct employment and food security for about 87% of the population, and 30-
35% of gross development product comes from agriculture, forestry, and fishing. Over 90% of 
the poor live in rural areas. Rural industry performance is generally static or declining, and, with 
only a few exceptions, rural employment is not expanding.1 Moreover the country’s demographic 
structure is young, and the population has expanded at 2.7% annually in the two decades 
before 2000. Lack of employment is a key factor facing a restless and increasingly frustrated 
rural population.2 Rural violence is common along major arterial roads, and urban violence has 
reached extreme levels, especially in the national capital, Port Moresby.  
 
2.  Although a number of insightful reviews have been written in recent years and the state 
of PNG’s rural economy is generally understood, action to remedy its decline has not been 
supported with adequate resources. A coherent strategy for the future is lacking. At the industry 
or sector level, however, ideas and plans as to the main priorities are clear but implementation 
arrangements and resources are not available. Industry priorities are not necessarily shared by 
the central Government, which has the responsibility for providing most budget resources. A 
national consensus is lacking with respect to what the main priorities and reforms should be, 
how they might be best sequenced, how they might be best implemented, and how the most 
important changes could be financed at a time of national fiscal crisis.  
 
B.  Outline Terms of Reference  
1.  Phase 1: Review and Participatory Strategy Development  
3.  Phase 1 will provide an overview of sector performance, a legislative and institutional 
framework, and a budget assessment prior to a series of participatory workshops that will be 
held  in  the  each  of  the  main  industry  centers.  The  outcome  of  the  workshops  will  be  a 
consensus view of the major reforms needed, and their priority. The consultants will work with 
the Department of National Planning and Rural Development to develop a consensus among 
the domestic agencies involved, which include Department of Agriculture and Livestock (DAL), 
National Agricultural Research Institute, Provincial Departments of Primary Industry, and the 
representative agencies for key agencies.3 Involvement of senior political representatives will be 
essential.

4.  Phase 1 will take 6 months to complete and require approximately 10 person-months of 
international consultants and 16 person-months of domestic consultants. It will consist of the 
following tasks, as described below. A project framework for phase 1 is also provided (Appendix 
1).  
 
5.  Sector  Review  and  Performance  Assessment.  The  consultants  will  conduct  an 
analytical review of the agriculture sector, and its recent performance and outlook based on 
indicators appropriate for the respective subsectors, including rural financial markets. Recent 
studies, reviews, socioeconomic projections, and lessons learned from past projects should be 
fully taken into account. Where appropriate, quantitative analyses will complement the existing 
reviews. The key constraints on developing a coherent strategy for agricultural and natural 
resource development will be identified in the paper. A sector outlook overview focused on the 
rural outlook for the next decade will be prepared to brief participants in various workshops and 
as background for various interest groups.  
 
6.  Legislative and Institutional Review. The legal and regulatory arrangements and the 
institutional mandates will also be reviewed. Attention will be placed on national and provincial 
laws and regulations and the effectiveness of enforcement. Impediments to improve market 
efficiency and service development will be identified. The consistency of this framework will be 
examined, especially with respect to overlapping jurisdictions, duplication of roles, and the need 
for streamlining of responsibilities. The delivery systems used by the various institutions in 
undertaking their duties will be examined to see where they are most and least effective in 
providing  services—especially  for  smallholder  farming  systems,  and  their  requirements  for 
reforms, changed structure, and capacity development. The main outputs of the key institutions 
will be examined in terms of service delivery for clients. Innovations in services or other areas of 
ongoing reform will be examined for replication in a wider context.  
 
7.  Policies  and  Strategies.  The  existing  policy  and  strategy  framework  will  also  be 
reviewed. Recent government papers and briefs prepared by the Department of Agriculture and 
Livestock, and relevant policies and plans of the key industries will be examined.4 The review 
will identify (i) whether the policy regime is supportive, adequate, and deliverable to support 
PNG’s complex farming systems and sustainable rural livelihoods; (ii) policy consistency and 
areas where perverse incentives are provided or encouraged and which conflict with market-
based principles; (iii) coherency between agencies and industries; (iv) areas for improved donor 
coordination; and (v) enforcement capacity.  
  
8.  Public  Expenditure  Review  and  Budget  Projections.  A  consolidated  financial 
statement of all relevant service agencies, government and nongovernment, and financial and 
marketing services, will show past trends and projections for the next 5-10 years from the 
current  base.  The  statement  will  also  include  personnel,  operation  and  maintenance,  and 
overhead costs. International comparisons with selected Pacific and Asian developing member

9.  Participatory  Industry  Workshops:  The  consultants  will  help  the  relevant  industry 
association/body  and  the  Government  organize  the  participatory  workshops.  Workshops 
(possibly one per industry for coffee, cocoa, oil palm, copra, tea, rubber, fisheries, livestock, 
minor export crops, and food crops) will be conducted for up to 3 days each as required. The 
workshops on the various crops and subsectors will (i) consider the enabling environment for 
investment  and  development;  (ii) discuss  and  agree  on the  key  constraints  to  sustainable 
development;  (iii)  examine  existing  industry  policies,  strategies,  and  plans  and  how  to 
implement/amend  them  as  needed;  (iv)  examine  service  delivery  effectiveness,  including 
financial services; and (v) recommend an action plan and the sequencing of necessary actions. 
The consultants will present the findings from the above work and collect feedback from major 
stakeholders, including government agencies, farmers and local communities, input and output 
marketing  agents,  traders  and  financiers,  research  bodies,  external  agencies,  and 
nongovernment  office.  The  main  outputs  from  the  workshops  will  be  identification  of  key 
strategy elements and ways to implement these strategies. Emphasis will be placed on gaining 
consensus  on  the  main  actions  needed,  and  phasing.  At  the  end  of  each  workshop,  the 
consultants will compile the results into set of recommendations in summary format.  
 
10.  Initial Project Preparation. Based on their extensive stakeholder consultations, the 
consultants will lay the groundwork for the ensuing project preparation, by making an initial 
identification of monitorable criteria and indicators, where the focus will be on outputs rather 
than inputs. The phase 1 consultants will also make preliminary suggestions regarding the 
potential project framework (logframe), as well as recommendations for the modality (sector 
development project or simple investment project). The consultants will also undertake further 
social screening to clarify and define any likely involuntary resettlement impacts, to help to 
refine the terms of reference for phase 2. 
 
2.  Phase 2: Project Preparation  
11.  The  results  of  the  industry  workshops  will  provide  the  broad  direction  for  project 
preparation in the phase 2. Following a 1-month break after phase 1, the Government, together 
with industry representative groups, will examine the outputs of the workshops and the report of 
phase 1 in a 5-day national policy seminar to be held at the beginning of month 8. Participation 
of senior government officials, including political representatives, will be essential to build a 
shared vision for the future and strong ownership of subsequent actions. The consulting team 
will  assist  in  this  process.  At  the  completion  of  the  national  workshop,  a  tripartite  review 
involving the Government, consultants, and Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be held. This 
meeting will confirm the priorities for the work of phase 2. During the tripartite review, agreement 
will be reached on an initial project framework (logframe) for the project, including monitorable 
criteria and indicators, focused on outputs rather than inputs. A critical focus for the policy 
seminar and the tripartite review will be to assess the appropriate mixture of reforms measures 
and complementary development activities to be pursued, and the appropriate modality (sector 
development program or investment project). The prospects of a viable project need to be 
thoroughly assessed before moving on to detailed project design. Project design will need to 
incorporate economic, social, and environmental considerations, following ADB requirements.  
 
12.  Phase 2 will take 5 months to complete and require approximately 14 person-months of 
international consultants and 20 person-months of domestic consultants. It will consist of the 
following tasks:  
 
(i)  National policy seminar. The national policy seminar at the beginning of phase 
2,  the  objectives,  major  outputs  and  the  sequencing  required  for  a

(ii)  Project  design.  Based  on  prior  consultative  process  and  feedback  from

(iii)  National stakeholder  workshop. Representatives will be invited to  a 4-day

13.  A second tripartite meeting will be held at the end of month 11 to review the draft project 
as outlined in the draft final report. If a consensus is not reached on the final project design and 
financing and implementation arrangements, a second national stakeholder workshop may be 
held to finalize the main elements of the proposed project. 
 
14.  A  critical  focus  of  the  project  design,  and  subsequent  implementation,  will  be  the 
development impact of the project. A fundamental aspect of project preparation will be the 
development  of  monitorable  criteria  and  indicators,  focused  on  outputs  rather  than  inputs. 
Indicators will get systematic attention during project preparation, by consultants and ADB staff. 
The project framework (logframe) will be the core design mechanism. All normal ADB standards 
and requirements for project preparation will be followed.
